Award.AwardTitle: BECS: Pattern Formation by Vascular Stem Cells: Control of Complex Biological Systems through Bottom-up and Top-down Approaches
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the mechanisms by which vascular-derived stem cells spontaneously organize into patterns, and then uses these mechanisms to devise some simple controls on pattern formation. Building on our previous work using Partial Differential Equation models of the developing stem cell culture system, we will develop a series of predictions addressing how altered boundary conditions change the occurrence, size, shape and other parameters of the pattern. We will extend our previous modeling efforts by incorporating cells and cell movement in the model, which had previously been purely chemical. We will also study how the mechanical and chemical properties of the substrate alter the evolving pattern, and how the features of cell proliferation and movement affect the pattern. Predictions will be tested in an experimental culture system of vascular-derived adult stem cells.

The process by which cells self-organize into structured patterns ("pattern formation") is essential to many biological processes. The development of the embryo, for example, can be viewed as a sequence of these processes. It is clearly important to understand the mechanisms of these processes in order to be able to do successful ?tissue engineering?. In the past, a common approach to tissue engineering has been to decide what patterns are desired, and then to attempt to use direct external controls to produce that pattern, without an understanding of the underlying biological organizational principles. However, biological systems are characterized by their capacity for self-organization, which can defeat and frustrate direct attempts at pattern control. Here, we propose to take advantage of the self-organizational behavior of stem cells to derive engineering approaches to the inverse problem of coaxing complex biological systems into a desired form. We believe that the shape of the boundary, the elastic and chemical properties of the surface on which they are grown, and the migratory tendencies of the cells are important contributors to pattern formation. We expect that insights gained from this study will have a positive impact on attempts to achieve tissue engineering of biological complex structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Cells self-organize into many distinct patterns to make tissues. This self-organization is governed by the reaction and diffusion of morphogens, chemicals that guide cell movement, growth and commitment. A growing tradition in tissue engineering is to use this morphogen-directed pattern formation to engineer tissues into desired patterns.

One powerful tool in this process is the use of mathematical models. In the period of this grant, we developed engineering applications of this idea, using the pattern formation process to produce desired patterns.

Our first application was to produce a new pattern: inhibitor spots or ‘holes’ in a 2-dimensional tissue culture. This was done by following the predictions of a mathematical model, using an experimental drug that enhanced cell movement. The concept of tissue that is interspersed by periodic holes is a model for spongy tissue such as bone, and our experiments suggest how such tissue can be formed.

In another study, we found that we could convert one pattern, disordered labyrinthine stripes, into a globally coherent pattern of parallel stripes. This global coherence was achieved through two tendencies: an inherent self-organization of cells to orient in the same direction as their neighbors, and a newly-discovered intrinsic tendency of these cells to turn right at fibronectin/polyethylene glycol interfaces.

We then used these tendencies to create engineered patterns such as large-scale radial patterns, large-scale concentric ring patterns, and multi-lobe structures of radial or concentric patterns, as is seen in tissues like the liver.

The results suggest that mathematical models of morphogenesis provide mechanistic explanations of pattern formation, including predictions of the results of interventions, and enable the experimenter to do “tissue engineering” using the self-organization tendencies of the cells involved.

 

Broader impacts

            Tissue engineering is one of the great goals of applied biomedicine. Exciting possibilities include the development of artificial skin for burn and wound victims, strengthening and developing bone to replace bone loss, and, generally, the development of artificial organs to replace diseased ones.

            The development of artificial tissue has been somewhat limited by a focus on cells (such as stem cells), without a lot of attention to how these cells organize into tissue. Our research, together with that of other groups using similar approaches, offers an advantage over what we feel are naïve approaches basically shooting a mass of stem cells into a tissue. This new approach uses inherent self-organizational mechanisms to produce desired tissue patterns.

            Our research on this project heavily involved graduate and undergraduate students. The 4 papers that came out of the project all had graduate students as first authors and at least one other undergraduate or graduate author.
